body_str: [Translation]: There are two applications for judicial review before the court in which the applicants are seeking to have set aside the decision of Marc Lamarre, Brian Doyle and Uwe Manski, in their capacity as delegates of the powers of investigation and hearing vested in the Superintendent of Bankruptcy under the
(R.S.C. 1985, c. B-3, as amended by S.C. 1992, c. 27) [the "
"], holding that they did not have jurisdiction to find ss. 14.01 and 14.02 of the
to be unconstitutional, or jurisdiction to declare those sections to be inoperative and contrary to the
(S.C. 1960, c. 44, reproduced in R.S.C. 1985, App. III) [the "

Pfeiffer & Pfeiffer has held a licence as a trustee in bankruptcy since 1980. The applicant Sydney Pfeiffer has also held such a licence since 1974. He is the president of the firm Pfeiffer & Pfeiffer, which administers more than 1,600 estates and whose personnel consists of two trustees and 48 employees. The intervenor Guylaine Houle, who also holds a licence as a trustee in bankruptcy, is a shareholder and director of Pfeiffer & Pfeiffer.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

During December 1991 and January 1992, the Superintendent of Bankruptcy, with the assistance of the personnel under his direction and control, conducted an audit of the activities of the applicants, and in April 1992 the applicants received a report prepared by Andy J. Blitzer, C.A.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

On December 11, 1992, Mr. Pfeiffer received a letter from Marc Mayrand, Deputy Superintendent of Bankruptcy (Operations), to which was attached a draft report recommending that the Superintendent cancel the applicants' trustee licence. The report noted flaws in the administration of some estates which violated the
, the Regulations, the Guidelines and the Policies. More specifically, the report pointed to the following anomalies:  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>
(a) investing consolidated estate funds in trust companies and treasury bills;  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>
(b) registering certificates of deposit of consolidated funds not in trust for estates;  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>
(d) withdrawing final fees without recognizing the interim draw already taken;  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>
(e) withdrawing fees in excess of the fees taxed;  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>
(f) delegating signing authority on checks (sic) to an unauthorized person.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

On April 28, 1993, the solicitor for Pfeiffer & Pfeiffer wrote a letter to the office of the Superintendent of Bankruptcy setting out a list of reasons why Pfeiffer & Pfeiffer should retain its trustee licence.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

On June 16, 1993, Marc Mayrand signed a report similar to the draft that had been submitted to the parties earlier, recommending nonetheless that the Superintendent of Bankruptcy, George F. Redling, cancel the applicants' trustee licence.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>
On December 31, 1993, the Superintendent of Bankruptcy informed the parties that under s. 14.01(2) of the

, he had delegated his powers and functions as Superintendent to a panel composed of Marc Lamarre, a retired judge, as Chairman of the panel, and Brian Doyle and Uwe Manski, both trustees in bankruptcy. Accordingly, the Superintendent issued a delegation instrument authorizing the panel to act in accordance with the powers conferred by the
. The panel's specific mandate is described in the delegation instrument as follows:  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>
"1. considering the report in respect of the trustee received by the Superintendent from the Deputy;  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>
"2. affording the trustee the opportunity to be heard required by subs. 14.02(1) of the
in respect of the Deputy's report and notice of intention to exercise the powers set out in paragraphs 14.01(1)(a) to (c) of the
in relation to the trustee's licence;  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

"3. determining, in conformity with the provisions of paragraphs 14.02(2)(b) and (c) and in consultation with the trustee and the Deputy or their respective counsel, the procedural rules that shall apply in the course of affording the trustee the opportunity to be heard;  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>
"4. conducting, under the presidency of the chairman, the hearing at which the trustee is given the opportunity to be heard;  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>
"5. causing, for the purposes of paragraph 14.02(2)(d) of the
, a stenographic, electronic or other record to be taken of the proceedings at which the trustee is given the opportunity to be heard;  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>
"6. considering the evidence and submissions of the trustee and the Deputy;  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

"7. deciding whether, on the balance of the evidence before the panel, the recommendation of the Deputy in respect of the license of the trustee should be accepted, varied or rejected, and, in accordance with subs. 14.02(4) of the
, to give the decision and the reasons for the decision of the panel in writing to the trustee and to the Deputy within ninety days after the conclusion of the hearing; and,  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

"8. where the panel accepts or varies the recommendation of the Deputy and decides to exercise the power to suspend or cancel the license of the trustee, directing, after hearing representations from the trustee and the Deputy, another or other trustees to deal, in the manner directed by the panel, with the property in the estates that were, immediately prior to the cancellation or suspension of the licence, under the administration of the trustee. <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>
On June 3, 1994, the applicants filed a "Motion for declaration of lack of jurisdiction" with the panel. They were arguing, primarily, that:  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>
are unconstitutional, in that they violate s. 7 of the
Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
are inoperative because they are inconsistent with paragraph 2(e) of the
"- the process of investigation and hearing established by ss. 14.01 and 14.02 of the
violate the impartiality requirements imposed by the principles of natural justice. <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>
Accordingly, they asked the panel to declare that it was not competent to proceed, having regard to the invalidity of ss. 14.01 and 14.02 of the

On September 1, 1995, the panel rendered its decision in which it concluded that it did not have jurisdiction to determine the constitutionality of the sections in question. It concluded as follows:  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>
"The tribunal and/or the Superintendent does not have and has never had the power in its enabling statute to review the constitutionality of its duties and the powers conferred on it by the
. No such power, whether express or implied, is found anywhere in the

"We have no jurisdiction to determine constitutional questions, or to made declarations that only the superior courts may make, or to determine the constitutional validity of the enabling statute under which our mandate was given to us.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>
"For the foregoing reasons, the two motions by the applicants Sydney H. Pfeiffer and Pfeiffer & Pfeiffer Inc. are denied. (sic) <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

That decision is the subject of this judicial review. However, on November 9, 1995, the respondent filed a motion to strike out the two originating notices of motion. On the consent of the parties, Mr. Justice Teitelbaum ordered that the motion be heard at the hearing on the merits. At the time of the hearing before me, the respondent chose not to argue that motion at any length, although it remains in the record. I shall therefore deal with it first.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>
1. Are these originating notices of motion premature, in that the decision of the panel is interlocutory, and should they accordingly be struck out?  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>
2. Did the panel err in concluding that it did not have jurisdiction to declare that ss. 14.01 and 14.02 of the
3. Are ss. 14.01 and 14.02 inoperative in that they are inconsistent with para. 2(e) of the
"14.01(1) The Superintendent, after making or causing to be made an investigation into the conduct of a trustee, may, where it is in the public interest to do so,  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>
(a) cancel the licence of a trustee;  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>
(b) suspend the licence of a trustee; or  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>
(c) place such conditions or limitations on the licence of a trustee as the Superintendent considers appropriate.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

"14.01(2) The Superintendent may delegate by written instrument, on such terms and conditions as are therein specified, any or all of the Superintendent's powers, duties and functions under paragraphs 1(a) to (c) or s. 14.01 or 14.03.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>
"14.01(3) Where the Superintendent delegates in accordance with subs. (2), the Superintendent or the delegate shall  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>
(a) where there is a delegation in relation to trustees generally, give written notice of the delegation to all trustees; and  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

(b) whether or not paragraph (a) applies, give written notice of the delegation of a power to any trustee who may be affected by the exercise of that power, either before the power is exercised or at the time the power is exercised.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

"14.02(1) Where the Superintendent intends to exercise any of the powers set out in paragraphs 14.01(1)(a) to (c), the Superintendent shall send the trustee written notice of the powers that the Superintendent intends to exercise and the reasons therefor and afford the trustee a reasonable opportunity for a hearing.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>
"14.02(2) At a hearing referred to in subs. (1), the Superintendent  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>
(a) has the power to administer oaths;  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>
(b) is not bound by any legal or technical rules of evidence in conducting the hearing;  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>
(c) shall deal with the matters set out in the notice of the hearing as informally and expeditiously as the circumstances and a consideration of fairness permit; and  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>
(d) shall cause a summary of any oral evidence to be made in writing.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

"14.02(3) The notice referred to in subs. (1) and, where applicable, the summary of oral evidence referred to paragraph 2(d), together with such documentary evidence as the Superintendent receives in evidence, form the record of the hearing.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

"14.02(4) The decision of the Superintendent after a hearing referred to in subs. (1), together with the reasons therefor, shall be given in writing to the trustee not later than 90 days after the conclusion of the hearing and may, where the Superintendent considers it in the public interest to do so, be made public after the decision has been given to the trustee.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

"14.02(5) A decision of the Superintendent given pursuant to subs. (4) is deemed to be a decision of a federal board, commission or other tribunal that may be reviewed and set aside pursuant to the Federal Court Act. <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

The Attorney General submitted that the application for judicial review brought by the applicants from the decision of the panel is premature because that decision was in fact an interlocutory decision. The respondent relied on the decision of the Federal Court of Appeal in

<FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> , in which Mr. Justice Létourneau held that as a general rule, time should not be spent on reviewing interlocutory decisions, except in special circumstances. According to the respondent, the court has jurisdiction to dismiss the originating notices of motion under its general power, as governed by s. 5 of the

The applicants argued, for their part, that it was not premature to raise the issue of bias before the panel. It is settled law that bias on the part of a tribunal must be raised without delay. For example, in
<FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  to raise the issue of bias at the first opportunity amounted to waiver of that ground for challenging the jurisdiction of the tribunal.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>
In my opinion, there is an initial procedural problem, since the
make no provision for dismissing a motion. (

<FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  (T.D.)) Although the Attorney General cited s. 5, it is used only in exceptional cases. In the instant case, the decision relates to the jurisdiction of the administrative tribunal to determine constitutional questions or make declaratory judgments. The tribunal held that it did not have jurisdiction to determine such a question. The same situation arose in
<FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  (T.D.), and the court decided the issue immediately on an application for judicial review.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>
<FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  review could be permitted in interlocutory cases on the question of jurisdiction, at p. 3:  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

"... where the motion itself is apt to be time consuming and where there is, as here, a clear question of jurisdiction which may determine the entire matter, common sense dictates, and rule 5 permits, that the court deal with the preliminary objection in advance. <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>
As well, it appears that judicial review of a decision of a tribunal relating to a question of jurisdiction may avoid the costs of a hearing on the merits. In
, [1974] 1 F.C. 22; 1 N.R. 422 (F.C.A.), at p. 34  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  the Federal Court of Appeal held:  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>
"In my view, the object of ss. 18 and 28 of the
is to provide a speedy and effective judicial supervision of the work of federal boards, commissions and other tribunals
with a minimum of interference with the work of those tribunals. Applying s. 11 of the
, with that object in mind, to the question raised by these s. 28 applications,

it must be recognized that the lack of a right to have the court review the position taken by a tribunal as to its jurisdiction or as to some procedural matter, at an early stage in a hearing, may well result, in some cases, in expensive hearings being abortive. On the other hand, a right, vested in a party who is reluctant to have the tribunal finish its job, to have the court review separately each position taken, or ruling made, by a tribunal in the course of a long hearing would, in effect, be a right vested in such party to frustrate the work of the tribunal.

In my opinion, since this issue involves an attack on the very existence of the tribunal, there is a special reason permitting judicial review at this stage of the proceedings. (Cases in which the court has intervened in interlocutory decisions:
<FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  (F.C.A.), at p. 140  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  "it is a final decision that disposes of a substantive question before the tribunal".  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>
Accordingly, the motion to strike is dismissed.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

While I have reached the same conclusion as Mr. Justice Noël, I shall not follow the same route as my colleague did. In my view, this is the approach that must be taken when the issue is whether the tribunal in question is a court of competent jurisdiction within the meaning of s. 24(1) of the

In the instant case, I do not believe that it is necessary to analyze the question from this standpoint, since, as Mr. Justice La Forest stated, the tribunal need not meet the definition of a court of competent jurisdiction. In my opinion, we must determine whether Parliament gave the tribunal, in its enabling statute, expressly or by implication, a duty to examine questions of law. This is the approach taken by the Court of Appeal in

What are the powers of the Superintendent or his delegates? The Superintendent has the power to suspend or cancel the licence of a trustee or place such conditions on the licence as he considers appropriate where it is in the public interest to do so, after affording the trustee an opportunity for a hearing.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

Of course, in order to do that, he must apply his enabling statute. In my opinion, however, that is not sufficient for us to conclude that he has the power to determine questions of law. As Mr. Justice Noël stated  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>
, (supra, para. [16]), all administrative tribunals may apply their enabling statute. We must analyse the statutory provision, the object of the provision and the general scheme of the
in order to determine whether Parliament intended to give the tribunal the power to decide questions of law.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

In the case at bar, after examining the statutory provisions, I conclude that the panel, through the Superintendent or his delegates, did not have the power to determine questions of law.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

Quite the contrary; Parliament has provided an informal process for hearings, and specified that the Superintendent is not bound by the rules of evidence. Matters must be dealt with as the circumstances and a consideration of fairness permit. There is nothing in these provisions to indicate any intention to give the panel responsibility for determining questions of law. In addition, Parliament did not deem it advisable to grant the panel certain powers of investigation under the
, R.S.C. 1985, c. I-11, which powers the Court of Appeal took into account in

For example, the enabling statute provided that the Board had to provide the applicant with a summary of the law applicable to the applicant's case and the Board's interpretation thereof, to hold hearings in camera if it considered that this would not be contrary to the public interest (such a finding necessarily involves points of law) and to determine the legal duty to maintain. I was compelled to conclude from that analysis that the panel could determine questions of law. This is not the case here. The panel therefore did not err in determining that it did not have the power to decide the constitutional questions submitted.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>
